results.title: Waltzing Matilda
results.creator_credit: Michael Chataway, Michael Cusack, John Morris and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description: In this humorous claymation dramatisation of Banjo Paterson’s famous poem, all of the characters, with the exception of the ill-fated sheep thief, are transformed into animals. Shot on a set designed to replicate Russell Drysdale’s Outback paintings, the film brings to life and explains the terminology of the lyrics.

results.title: The Plains of Heaven
results.brief_description: In this inversion of the buddy-film two technicians manning a tracking station on the High Plains pursue diametrically opposed ways of coping with the isolation. The ageing Cunningham seems to be rejuvenated by and obsessed with the landscape while the younger Barker withdraws into the station and its attendant technology. Return to Barker’s Melbourne becomes a descent into a fragmented, nightmare cityscape. The denial of cause and effect explanations for behaviour invites a metaphysical interpretation of this ambiguously down-side existential drama of disorientation and alienation not dissimilar to Werner Herzog’s visionary dramas although without the German director’s quirky black humour. Cast: Richard Moir, Reg Evans, Gerard Kennedy.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Mick
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Mick’s obsession with trains began when he was a young boy growing up in Prague. He began constructing his model train world for his grandchildren many years ago. However, when they grew up and lost interest, Mick’s interest continued to grow. Mick’s shed contains another world. In it are miniature houses, people, trees and animals, all set around a train line with a “Swiss” alpine backdrop complete with snow capped mountains. Mick spends his time in his shed perfecting his miniature world and making continuous repairs, additions and alterations. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Phu & Phong
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Phu and Phuong’s shed is a serious mechanical jewel box. The exterior, a classic corrugated shed, gives no real impression of what can be found inside. The shed houses both of the brother’s prized possessions – their cars. The boys weekends and most evenings are spent in the shed polishing and cleaning the beloved, gleaming machinery, listening to music and generally just being with the cars. Phu’s low and sleek Nissan Turbo has everything that can open and shut – all digital of course, with every ‘after market’ improvement possible. Electric blue LEDs glow, exotic dials flicker, buttons and knobs are there for the pressing and tweaking: it’s a bit like having a low-flying spaceship in a suburban shed. For Phu and Phuong, the shed has been there for most of their lives. As kids they watched their father looking after his cars in the shed, which created their own interest in shed activities. Surrounded by their father’s ornate topiary, the shed dominates their small backyard. It was built to cram in four cars, which makes the morning departures something of a family joke. The brothers enjoy taking their cars out for a cruise on Sunday but the best part is then returning for hours in the shed to polish and love it some more. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Dimitri
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Dimitri lives in a suburban house in Adelaide. As we meet Dimitri we discover his intense love of Greek musical instruments. He is one of a few in Australia who makes bouzoukis, ouds and baglamas. We hear how Dimitri first got interested in his craft and how he made a special journey from Australia to Poland to learn from a master craftsman. Dimitri works in his brand new purpose built shed in the backyard, as he likes the flexibility of working all hours. We watch how Dimitri builds musical instruments and also welcomes and attracts his friends and colleagues to the shed to share in the unique sound of those instruments he loves and makes. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Saroop & Omer
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Set in the lush Riverland in South Australia, we meet a Sikh man, Saroop, and his Bosnian friend, Omer. Saroop owns 400 acres of fruit growing land on the River Murray. He’s been there for 25 years after coming out from the Punjab. Saroop has several sheds with large tractors and spraying machinery as well as one open-sided shed where he and Omer work on repairing things and on long term experiments - such as the budcutting machine they have worked on for several years. They call this shed “Omer’s Lab”. Saroop and Omer work hard at reusing lots of existing scrap to construct new things and replace parts on others. They are extremely inventive and are proud they have saved hundreds of dollars by making things more mechanical and efficient. This interstitial explores the close friendship between two different cultural backgrounds. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Attilio
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
Oe of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Attilio, a retired fitter and turner, is part of a powerful Italian tradition of high quality artisanship. He still works at home, doing small, specialised jobs. His basic galvanised iron shed is lined with tools of the trade - boxes and shelves filled with mostly metallic bits and pieces that get pieced together with absolute passion and craft. Attilio is also an entertainer - a funny guy and the life of the party. He has produced many CDs of his songs and is regularly booked for events by the South Australian Italian community. Attilio’s taverna is an open-sided room with a big table and a gas stove at one end - complete with an espresso machine for making short blacks (sometimes with a dash of the grappa!). In his taverna Attilio spends time with his brother Joe and his friends, enjoying Italian food and the fruits of his other labour – wine making. So Attilio’s backyard has two sheds – one for sharing friendship and entertainment, the other for the serious work. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson

Oe of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Attilio, a retired fitter and turner, is part of a powerful Italian tradition of high quality artisanship. He still works at home, doing small, specialised jobs. His basic galvanised iron shed is lined with tools of the trade - boxes and shelves filled with mostly metallic bits and pieces that get pieced together with absolute passion and craft. Attilio is also an entertainer - a funny guy and the life of the party. He has produced many CDs of his songs and is regularly booked for events by the South Australian Italian community. Attilio’s taverna is an open-sided room with a big table and a gas stove at one end - complete with an espresso machine for making short blacks (sometimes with a dash of the grappa!). In his taverna Attilio spends time with his brother Joe and his friends, enjoying Italian food and the fruits of his other labour – wine making. So Attilio’s backyard has two sheds – one for sharing friendship and entertainment, the other for the serious work. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.

results.title: Blokes and sheds - Des
results.creator_credit: Robi Watt, Sarah Wishart, Australian Film Commission, SBS Independent, South Australian Film Corporation and Mark Thomson
results.brief_description:
One of 12 minidocos about blokes and their sheds in South Australia.
Des lives and works on his farming property in the historical German region of The Barossa Valley in South Australia. He has a hint of a German accent – all the more surprising since he is the third generation of his family born in Australia. There are many sheds on the property housing equipment that belonged to his father and grandfather before him. In a beautifully well-preserved hay thatched shed, a vast collection can be viewed as an almost historical “museum” to early farming technology. Des knows where everything is - although some of it has probably not been used for 20 or 30 years. But the equipment is still in working condition and we witness Des using a combination of that equipment as part of his working day. Based on the book by Mark Thomson.
